values: Well, I think it's about time to revive this journal, seeing as the last entry was over a year ago... ...and what better to start things off than with the latest big news from the show that in that time has joined Lost and Battlestar Galactica to form a 3-way tie for my favourite: Doctor Who. I must admit that a lot of my love for this show is due to the delightful David Tennant and his marvellous, endearingly quirky portrayal of the Doctor. So it was with some dismay that I heard the news last October of his retirement: how could any actor ever fill the ratty old Converse of MY Doctor? After months of wild speculation -- my personal choices were James Callis or Hugh Laurie -- the Eleventh Doctor was announced on January 3, in a special Doctor Who Confidential, as this guy: By lucky coincidence, I happened to be in London at the time, & was able to watch the announcement live on telly whilst getting ready to go watch My Doctor pop his clogs as Hamlet -- by unbelievably lucky coincidence, since I showed up at the theatre expecting the understudy. Before the announcement that David Tennant was making his triumphant return to the boards of the Novello Theatre that night, the New Doctor was, unsurprisingly, the main topic of conversation amongst the audience. The main reaction was largely the same as that of headline writers the world over: "Doctor Who?" The next day, browsing for something to read at the airport, I was amazed to see that the New Doctor was front-page news. Can I just say how much I adore the immensely wide-spread love for DW in Britain? I can't think of a single TV show in North America for which a casting decision would earn a front-page mention in pretty much every newspaper, not to mention a highly-rated special on prime-time TV to announce it in the first place. On my 9-hour + plane ride, I had plenty of time to read the articles and form an opinion of this young interloper. I struggled mightily to give him a fair chance -- after all, all I was judging him on was a single interview and a couple of photos. He didn't seem like a terrible choice: he was delightfully eccentric in the interview, after all. But still! He was so young! He had emo hair! And, worst of all, he was Not David Tennant. I remained ambivalent, but granted him a grudging sort of acceptance. Time passed. DT returned to film his final episodes. Planet of the Dead aired, and My Doctor saved the world once again. This Matt Smith guy faded into a distant future. Until this morning that is, when pictures were released of him as the Doctor, costume, assistant and all: And you know what? Ambivalance be damned, I kind of love him! I mean, just look at how adorable those two are. (And so what if as of Sunday the Doctor and I will be the same age. Well, not "the Doctor", who is after all 900-and-something, but the actor portraying him.) I love that they've given him a old-man look, to contrast his youth. He looks like a rather uncool sort of teacher, which seems quite appropriate. And while he's kept his hair it's been tamed just enough, into a style I'm rather fond of. Overall, thumbs-up from me. Plus, bonus points for the braces even if they are the clip-on kind. (What would Captain Jack say?) I do love a man in braces, strangely enough. And even if his companion does have the somewhat questionable last name of Pond & look relatively contemporary (I had been hoping for a historical companion), I like that she gets to keep her Scottish accent -- and bonus points for being a readhead. (Gingers represent!) And they look even better in the filming pics. (Spoilers!) Seeing him in costume next to the Tardis, he really does look like the Doctor. My first thought on seeing the costume was John Smith, my second was Indiana Jones at his day job. Both references seem appropriate, adventurers disguised as schoolteachers. So complain away, everyone, but I like it. With all these new photos, I'm actually really excited to meet the Eleventh Doctor; I think the way they've been introducing him is perfect. Announce the casting over a year in advance, so everyone has a long time to get over their inevitable negative reaction, then six months later announce the costume and companion; repeat negative reaction, & coming to terms with. By the time the first episodes actually air more than eight months from now, pretty much everyone will have gotten over their fear of change & be feverishly anticipating the New Doctor. Of course, we've still got the bound-to-be-heartbreaking finale for the Tenth Doctor to get through first...

To celebrate the return of Lost, a picspam recap of epic proportions!
So far, all three premieres have opened with an eye...er, opening: And in seasons 2 & 3, the owner of said eye put on some music... And went about his or her day... Until something weird happened, and then it turned out we were actually on Craphole Island. SURPRISE! But, that was before Lost went "Through the Looking Glass" and forward to the future in the last season finale. So this year, after almost nine months with no Lost, millions of people tune in, expecting eyes, music, and cunning misdirection, and the first thing they get to see is... a pile of papayas on the beach? WTF? Psych! We're back in Kansas, Toto: they're actually outside a warehouse in Los Angeles! And also involved in a high-speed car chase. And then things get a bit meta, because the car chase we're watching on TV? Well, now we're watching on TV as someone on TV watches...on TV. But who's watching it? Here's a hint: he likes to top off his morning OJ with a splash of vodka. Only a splash? Well, then it can't possibly be Jack. He'd be drinking it straight out of the... Wait, it IS Jack! And he doesn't have the hideous beard yet! So, does that mean we're not in the future? But, that car DID look awfully familiar. And Jack seems to recognise it too... So, who could be on the run from the law? Kate? Sawyer? ...Hurley? Oh, right: that's his vintage Camaro, limited edition Daddy Issues model. Jack should really look into getting one of those. So Hurley tries a foot-dash away from the fuzz, bless him, but not surprisingly he doesn't get very far. And then we find out for certain that it's 2007, because he tries on the whole 'But I'm a Celebrity!' defense for reckless driving. At least he's wearing underwear. Hope you're not drunk, Hurley. Jacob does NOT approve of drinking and driving. And speaking of Ana-Lucia, the detective interviewing Hurley is none other than her old partner, who is apparently the one person who misses her. I almost feel sorry for him, and then I remember how much I hated her, so...nope. Anywho, the important thing in this scene seems to be that Hurley lies about having known Ana-Lucia. Unless he just mentally blocked her out because she was so unpleasant. Plus, he looks really, really sad: And then, a mere 5 minutes in, we get the first WTF, freeze-frame moment of the year: the 2-way mirror into the interrogation room turns into a window to the ocean, and Charlie appears with a message on his hand -- just before the glass breaks, flooding the room with water. (Not unlike the way he died.) So, Hurley starts freaking out, as you do when when death seems imminent. But when Mr. Ana-Lucia comes back, everything's back to normal. He threatens to lock Hurley up in the nut house, and Hurley hugs him with gratitude. ...As you do when forced incarceration in a mental institution seems imminent. ...But back on dear old Craphole Island, Hurley is still his lovable old self, engaging in some expository banter on the walkie with Jack. It's just as well he can't see the saucy wink Jack throws Ben's way though. Oh, Jack -- Tom isn't even in the ground yet! Then we get a sequence where everyone says how happy they are to be going home, just to up the dramatic irony, because we have seen the future, brothah, and some unspecified Terrible Thing has happened to make everyone miserable and/or dead. But for now, Kate can be happy about going home to death row... And Rose can be happy that her cancer will come back; Claire that she can be a single mother on welfare; and Sun... well, Sun is the only one who really DOES have a reason to be happy, because leaving the Island means she might not die after all. But Jack doesn't have time to be happy about going home to his dead dad and ex-wife, because he's too busy being thrilled to bits that he finally gets to kill Locke. That's just one of the many sacrifices he makes as leader, and don't you forget it. Even Alex has decided that the fact the mother she thought was dead turned out to be the crazy lady living in the woods, and the man she thought was her father actually kidnapped her as a baby and is now beaten bloody and tied to a tree is a great reason to ignore both of them and have a romantic picnic with her boyfriend. Teenagers. But one person who refuses to join in the happiness, for fear that he might be stripped of his membership in the Evil Genius Club, is Ben. He will insist on telling everyone that they're going to die, for which Rousseau thanks him by punching him in the face. Ah, happy families -- they're all alike. But Hurley can always be counted on for some happiness. Back on the beach, he's telling Bernard that he can't wait to get home & go back to being poor. (He'd better hope Walt doesn't find him, to collect his backgammon winnings.) Then, to show how happy he is, he re-enacts a scene from Baywatch by running in slow motion across the beach. He cannonballs into the water, and as the happiness builds, so does the tension: there's too much happiness! Too much! Something has to go wrong soon, this is Lost! Sure enough, when he surfaces, the bad news has arrived in the form of Desmond, the Angel of Death. The sexy, sexy Angel of Death. Everyone's very excited to see him: usually characters away from the beach camp at the finale take several episodes to make their way back! But Desmond's all worked up about it being Not Penny's Boat, and wants to stop Jack from contacting them. Only Hurley notices the obvious, and wants to know where Charlie is. Duh, Hurley: didn't you watch the recap that was just on? How about the pop-up video rerun last night? The previously? (I swear, I've watched Charlie die four times already this week.) Apparently not, so Desmond breaks the news. This causes great sadness all round. Hot, smouldering sadness. Meanwhile, Jack's chatting to his new BFF Minkowski. But Minkowski totally gives him the brush-off, and asks to speak to Naomi. But Jack doesn't want Naomi to take away his new friend, so he does the worst job of lying ever, & tells him that she went to...uh, get some firewood! Yeah, firewood, that's it! But when he looks over to check on Naomi, she's run away! So he just HANGS UP on Minkowski. Now there's no-one to be his friend. And also no-one to rescue them. Great plan, Jack. After the break, the folks at the beach are faced with a dilemma over what to do with Charlie's warning. And I am faced with a dilemma over whether to side with Sawyer (who wants to tell Jack) or Sayid (who doesn't). Hurley solves the argument by throwing the walkie into the ocean. Simple AND effective! The others (& The Others) could learn from him. Back at the radio tower, Rousseau interrupts Jack's handing out of sticks to redshirts to tell him that she's found Naomi's trail. And this is his reaction: (yes, this is vital to the plot, & no, I'm not just putting this in as an excuse to laugh at Jack's ridiculous faces. But as it is here: Ha-ha!) So Jack takes one last opportunity to boss everyone around before heading off with Rousseau & Ben to find Naomi. (Is that blue-shirted redshirt smoking? If he's been saving that cigarette til the moment of rescue, he is going to be PISSED OFF when the boat people kill everyone instead.) But then Kate comes running up with an idea so great, maybe this time Jack will finally let her in his secret fort. "Jack, Jack! I found a different bloody trail leading off into the jungle. I think we should follow both of them because we don't know which one's Naomi's." "Silly Kate! Tracking's for boys. Now give me a hug, then you be a good girl and go with the other women and children down to the beach. Leave the tracking to people who know what they're doing: a surgeon, a Crazy French Lady, and our shifty-eyed dog prisoner." Ben likes to watch. (Note: This shot seems so weird now because it will BE IMPORTANT LATER.) Back on the beach, the villagers have gotten up a posse to warn the good doc about the folks on Not Penny's Boat. Sawyer's got a big gun. (Also: Gratuitous explosions heroic pose with gun & pithy catchphrases? Sounds familar.) Hurley shouldn't be so worried, though: look how happy he is in the future, wearing his pyjamas all day long, and playing Connect-4 without a care in the world. ...That is, until THIS guy shows up. He doesn't look at all ominous, does he? His name is Abaddon, which means 'Destroyer', but hey, I'm sure that's just a coincidence, right? Anyway, he and Hurley have a nice little chat over a (Symbolism Alert!) chessboard, and in front of a chalkboard with a drawing of (Easter Egg Alert!) an island, a boat, and a shark. He works for Oceanic, and he just wants to offer Hurley an 'upgrade' to a nicer nuthouse, that's all, no strings attached. Only he must have 'forgotten' his business cards at home. Then he asks Hurley if they're still alive, and Hurley's like, I left that damn island because I couldn't deal with this level of creepiness, damnit! But when everyone looks over at him, he's vanished. Maybe he left a trail (or two) behind they can track? Back on the island, it's Freaky Friday time when Sawyer wants to help Hurley by talking about Charlie's death, while Hurley's all strong & silent man of action. So Sawyer catches back up with the rest of the posse, but it doesn't take Hurley long to regret his "I vant to be alone" stance as he gets lost in the dark jungle, a creepy breeze picks up, and the mysterious whispers start. And then he comes face to face with the Shrieking Shack. A light comes on inside. And, unique amongst these characters, Hurley has the only rational response: "Uh-oh." Elsewhere in the jungle, Rousseau has reached a dead end on Naomi's trail, and Jack has a little difficulty comprehending the fact that he was wrong. Of course, Ben can't pass up the opportunity to put Jack in his place with one of his brilliant lines: "Better call the boat, and tell them she's getting a really big bundle of firewood." Awesome. I'm more shocked here by the fact that Jack actually reaches for phone, seemingly to take Ben's advice & call the freighter, than I am by the fact the phone's missing. And really, Jack makes himself such an easy target for Ben, who's only too happy to tell him that Kate took the phone when she hugged him goodbye. And that she found the right trail. "But you wouldn't listen to her, so I guess she's taken matters into her own hands." The Others must have satellite tv -- Ben's seen this show before! "But look on the bright side, at least somebody around here knows what they're doing." Is it weird that I like the villain so much more than the hero right now? Sure enough, Kate has redeemed herself from the role of Jack's doormat that she played for much of last season. Not only is she hot on Naomi's trail, she's having a good old chinwag with Jack's pal Minkowski on the phone. But this Minkowski guy must be a real jerk, cause Kate hangs up on him too. If I was him I'd figure that these people don't want to be rescued, and just leave. But Kate has bigger problems than that right now: a tree has just started bleeding on her. Oh, that's okay, it's just Naomi. She must've taken a cue from poor Charlie & been hanging out with Treebeard. But she manages to undo all the smarts Kate had just managed to build up for herself by taking her captive. For a professional fugitive, Kate sure does seem to get caught a lot. Anywho, Minkowski just happens to call back right then, and Naomi gets Kate to give her the phone. While she doesn't let on about being stabbed in the back, she does ask Minkowski to tell her sister that she loves her, which could either be vitally important later on, or totally meaningless. It's hard to tell sometimes. And as luck would have it, Naomi has just enough time to fix the plot device technical problems before she snuffs it for good. FINALLY, we get back to Hurley, chez Jacob. He doesn't look as surprised as you might think to see a spooky cabin in the middle of the jungle, but hey, after the polar bears & black smoke monsters and all the other craziness, this might be the most NORMAL thing they've found on the island. So he goes to peer in the window. A bit depressing, no? Too bad Tom's dead, maybe he could've fixed the place up a bit for Jacob, and then he might not be so angry. And Kate could make him some new curtains, I hear she's quite the expert at that. So at first, the place looks like it's empty, despite the lit oil lamp on the table. But then -- fingers on the pause buttons, everyone! -- the second WTF, freeze-frame Easter Egg moment of the season: CHRISTIAN SHEPHARD IS SITTING IN JACOB'S CHAIR. Of course, Hurley doesn't know who Christian Shephard is, or even that only very special, Chosen One-types can see Jacob at all, nor, unfortunately, can he hear everyone yelling this at their TVs. So he very sensibly just stands and stares with his best WTF expression on. That is, until this scary, mysterious eye suddenly pops up right in front of him. It is at this point that Hurley loses it & runs for the hills, screaming for help. Meanwhile, the audience at home starts yelling out the names of every character who's ever appeared on the show whose eye that might be. Jacob! Charlie! Locke! Mikhail! Steve! Scott! That one guy who was in the background for a second in Season 1! Hurley looks back to make sure no ghosts are chasing him, only to see that the cabin has completely vanished. Not one to look a gift horse in the mouth, he turns back around to continue on his way -- only to see the cabin has MOVED & is now right in front of him. And for full horror-movie effect, the door slowly creaks open. This time, he tries closing his eyes & counting to five. Man, is Kate going to be angry when she realises that Jack tells their special story to anyone who'll listen. When he opens his eyes, the cabin's gone. (Teach me your secret sometime, Hurley?) He's so relieved, he trips over a log & falls on the ground. This time when he opens his eyes, Locke is looming over him. Damn, thinks Hurley. I asked for Libby, naked. Hurley fills Locke in on the whole Not Penny's Boat deal, & Locke spies an prime opportunity to use some of his newly-acquired, Benry-patented mind trickery in order to win Hurley over to his side. Locke & Hurley catch up with the rest of the beach posse at the cockpit. Hurley gets an enthusiastic welcome; Locke, not so much. At this point, Locke's done so much crazy shit that I'm having trouble keeping track of who wants to kill him for what. Good thing Sayid clarifies that HE's mad over the blowing-up of the submarine. Luckily for Locke, he's interrupted by noises in the jungle, which means it's lock and load time, boys. It's the radio tower refugees, who have managed to stumble upon the beach posse's exact location. This can only mean one thing: happy reunion montage! But not everyone has someone to hug: And, saddest of all, Desmond goes to break the news to Claire, but Hurley cuts him off, and approaches Claire with a grim face & accompanied by rising swells of Sad Death Music. She's already guessed by the time he gets to her, but he confirms her fears, and they have a good cry on each others' shoulders. Most traumatic experiences on the Island bring on a flashback, but this one induces a flashforward. Hurley's still at the sanitarium, sitting outside & painting an Arctic scene. Just when we're wondering what this has to do with Charlie's death, a fellow crazy tells Hurley that someone's watching him. And when he looks up, it's not the expected Creepy Guy from earlier, but... CHARLIE! Wow, death sure has been kind to you! And it looks like Boone got you in to see his hairdresser. Anyway, he's all, "Hey man, just popped round for a chat. And I wouldn't say no to a cup of tea if you've got one." "By the way, I had a dream once where you were wearing a robe just like that." But Hurley doesn't seem to be very glad to see him. Probably, you know, on account of him being dead and all. A way to tell that Charlie's dead? He doesn't get all huffy when he recounts how Hurley ran away from him in the convenience store. A way to tell Lost has seriously picked up the storytelling pace? It's only 3/4 through this episode, and already a question posed at the beginning has been answered. "I am dead. But I'm also here," Charlie paradoxes. [Excellent. That just won me 10 bucks in a bet with my sister.] But Hurley has had experience with imaginary friends, and won't believe him. So Charlie proves his existance by slapping him. I guess Hurley doesn't remember how his other imaginary friend was also able to slap him (and throw coconuts at him) even though he DIDN'T actually exist. Anyways, they finally sit down & have quite a touching little chat where Hurley gets to achieve some closure in Charlie's death. But then Charlie reveals the real reason he's there: to serve as Hurley's conscience and/or an emissary from the Island. There's something Hurley has to do, but he's hiding from it. "They need you." Hurley tries the old "I'm not listening, lalala" trick, before he breaks out the big guns of closing his eyes and counting to five. Once again, it works: he's left on his own at the mental hospital. Back on the Island, I'm not sure whether Claire's sadder over Charlie being dead, or that awful wig she's now wearing. And then Jack barrels into this touching emotional scene, and kind man that he is, he thoughtfully decides that this is the moment to finish his vendetta against Locke by knocking him to the ground & holding a gun to his head. Juliet briefly tries to reason with Jack, but alas she lacks Kate's ability to break up a fight with a single word. Locke's pretty confident though, cause he knows that Jacob will sic Ol' Smokey on Jack if he tries anything. But Jack's not about to let Locke out-crazy him, so he does, in fact, shoot him. ...but luckily the gun's not loaded. Jack, if Ben couldn't kill Locke, I hardly think you're going to manage it. Jack resorts to some good old-fashioned punching instead, until Sayid & Sawyer finally pull him away. We've sure come a long way in three months, haven't we boys? Welcome to what is sure to be an intelligent & mature debate between your leaders, the Man of Science & the Man of Faith. Up first, the Man of Faith: "Everything I did was in your best interests." And with the rebuttal, the Man of Science: "You're INSANE!" Hmmm, present events seem to suggest this is a case of pot vs kettle, so point to MoF for appearing the MORE resonable of the two. MoF: "I never did anything to hurt any of you." MoS: "All you ever did was blow up every chance we had of getting off this island." Well, there's no denying the truth in that statement. Point to MoS. But Jack loses the next point: when he accuses Locke of killing Naomi, lawyer Ben reminds everyone: "Well, technically he didn't kill her -- yet." Ben sure has great comic timing. Then Kate appears, just in time to say, "Yes, he did. She just died." I can only wonder how long she's been standing off in the shadows, waiting for the best moment to make a dramatic entrance. So, Kate's all proud that she's gotten the phone fixed, and brought it back for Jack -- and she can also report that Naomi covered for them (well, for Locke). But Locke rains all over her parade by remaining convinced that it's all just part of some master plan to get the rest of the freighter folk to the Island so they can begin wreaking havoc. He plans to go to the barracks and live in a house lined completely with tin foil so their mind rays can't get him. He makes his case convincing by utilising the knowledge from all those nights spent eating dinner in front of the TV: "If you want to live, you'd better come with me." Jack makes his case against Locke by utilising the knowledge from all those days spent being beaten up at school: "No-one's going anywhere with you, John, because they're not crazy." We are saved from another scintillating Jack/Locke schoolyard yelling match when Hurley speaks up, much to everyone's surprise. "He's not crazy." Well, Hurley should know from crazy. Hurley also knows how to win over a crowd much better than the other two crazies leaders, so he launches into a heartfelt, emotional speech (backed up by Ye Olde Sad Death Music again) about how Charlie died to save them... ...But that he realised something at the last moment, so his final act was to warn them. [Charlie's death scene count: 5] "So I'm not listening to you. I'm listening to my friend. I'm listening to Charlie," he concludes before going over to stand with Locke. In what should be no surprise to anyone, Jack is moved to tears by this. I was going to say that this is because everyone isn't following his orders, but Hurley's speech was very moving, & I just realised that this is the first Jack's heard of Charlie's death, so I'll give him the benefit of the doubt. And besides, it just wouldn't be a season premiere if Jack didn't cry at least once: So the survivors split into two tribes. Joining Hurley on Team Locke are: Claire, Rousseau & Ben (Who hilariously asks Jack's permission first), Alex & Karl, A bunch of redshirts who don't get closeups, cause no-one cares about them, And finally, agonisingly, Sawyer: When Kate, with a note of desperation in her voice, asks him what he's doing, he replies, "Same thing I've always done: surviving." Something else he's always done, & looks like he's right back to doing here? Hating himself. Kate's not used to those she loves leaving her -- usually it's the other way round. She looks betrayed, abandoned -- and like she kinds wants to go with him. She stays with Jack, though. Also on Team Jack: Desmond, Sayid, Juliet, Rose & Bernard, Sun & Jin (although we don't see them), and the rest of the redshirts. Once they're divided, it starts to rain -- never a good sign on this island. "You know where to find us when you change your mind," are Locke's confident parting words. I'm betting those who chose Team Locke are feeling pretty smug right now, knowing they're heading to warm, dry beds, hot showers & rooves over their heads. For better or for worse, though, the decisions are made, and the two tribes go their separate ways. With a few last longing glances. Hurley walks off right into the future, where it's sunny, & he's shooting some hoops by himself. Even though he's wearing slippers & a dressing gown, which I would think might get in the way, he never misses a shot. Then his third visitor announces himself, & this one is neither creepy nor dead, but a relaxed and happy-looking Jack. Aw -- what a difference from both his own flashforward, & his present on-Island self. He exposits that he was in the neighbourhood on a consult, & thought he'd drop in. He suggests a game of HORSE. As they play, they make expository small talk. Jack sucks at basketball, and it isn't long before he's an H-O. Unlike Island Jack, Future Jack seems cool with not being the best at everything. I like Future Jack. He also drops this gem: "I'm thinking about growing a beard." "You'd look weird with a beard, dude." Yeah, I'm going to have to agree with Hurley on this one. But just when it looks like Jack only stopped by to rub in how much better his off-Island life is than Hurley's, Hurley cuts to the chase: "You checking to see if I went nuts? If I was going to tell?" Like Abaddon, once his bluff is called, Jack gets straight to the point: "Are you?" Hurley doesn't answer, so Jack goes to leave. (Ah, now there's Island Jack.) But Hurley stops him with an apology -- a mysterious apology (Is there any other kind on this show?): "I'm sorry I went with Locke. I should have stayed with you." Jack graciously(!) accepts the apology, but Hurley keeps going, hinting around the Big Secret that the Oceanic Six seem to be keeping. "I don't think we did the right thing, Jack. I think it wants us to come back. And it's going to do everything it can..." "We're never going back!" Watch out for falling Anvils of Dramatic Irony! As well as Anvils of Foreshadowing, as Hurley calls after him, "Never say never, dude!" Back on the Island, Jack thanks everyone who stayed with him by abandoning them to stand alone by the cockpit, listen to Morrissey , & cry. Kate joins him, and they reminisce about all the good times they had there, back when Charlie was still alive, and they all saw the pilot get eaten by the monster, and then had to run for their lives. But just when they're thinking that maybe the Island is so great they don't want to leave it after all, OMG! The rescue chopper appears. Naturally, it's flying a bit erratically, as though it might crash. As they watch, someone parachutes out. Jack and Kate run to find their rescuer -- and hope the rescuer won't need rescuing. "Are you Jack?" So it begins...

So, in the Lost countdown I've had going in my head for quite some time now (exactly how long, I'm a bit embarased to say, but it's long enough that I've had to adjust it several times to allow for new premiere dates) has hit 23 days. And 23, as any Lost fan worth her salt knows, 23 is one of The Numbers. In celebration of this milestone, and in conjunction with me being rather bored due to a) being currently unemployed; and b) there being NOTHING on tv -- seriously, nothing -- I thought it might be fun to look at all the signifigant uses of the number 23 in Lost -- with pictures! In Season 1, it was the gate from which Oceanic Flight 815 left...
Meanwhile, Jack & Rose (& Bernard, til he went to the bathroom) were seated in Row 23...
And Ray the farmer got a $23,000 reward for turning fugitive Kate in to the marshal.
In Season 2, it was Penny's address in London when Desmond wrote to her from prison:
(I just noticed that even though Desmond's return address is in Essex, the letters are postmarked in Knightsbridge, their destination. I think that's an oops, prop people!)
And in Season 3, who could forget creepy Room 23, used by the Others for brainwashing horny teenage boys!
And, because I had just that much time, I also took a screencap of the 23rd second of the 23rd minute of the 23rd hour of each season. (Yeah, I think I really need to find a job. Soon.) Interesting that it's all closeups of main characters -- and that, as usual, Jack is over-represented. Still, I think it's a good reflection of where the show's at in each season. In Season 1, "Exodus, Part I":
It's Jack. Crying. Over his Daddy Issues. Hooray. Actually, it's right after the (rather touching, even to my cold and shriveled heart) scene where (shirtless, sweaty) Sawyer tells Jack about the conversation he had with Christian Shepherd in Sydney, thus letting Jack know that his dad is proud of him after all. Aw. Well, at least I think that's what was going on there. I was a bit distracted by all the shirtlessness and sweatiness going on with Sawyer. Plus the exquisitely tortured look in his eyes as his better instincts won out in a fierce internal battle. Oh, and this is immediately followed by a scene in which Kate begs Jack to allow her to tag along on his adventure to the mysterious Black Rock. Which he patronisingly agrees to. So, I reckon that's a pretty good snapshot of the show. Or, at least the love-triangle piece of it. In Season 2, from the first hour of the finale, "Live Together, Die Alone":
It's drunken Desmond! Drinking some more! And looking like a pirate! Very suitable for his first flashback episode, a 2-hour extravaganza during which he became one of my favourite characters. So this actually seems like a pretty good snapshot of where the show's at at that point: new characters have been introduced, the contents of the hatch have come to light, and we're moving beyond the plane crash and deeper into the island mythology. Plus, I'm sure that Desmond, Penny, and esp. Penny's dad are all much more involved with the Island than we currently know. And in Season 3, from the second hour of "Through the Looking Glass":
And here again we have Jack crying! Only this time, it's beardy flash-forward Jack, strung out on prescription pain meds. I think what I enjoy most about the flash-forward is finally seeing Jack admit he was wrong -- and Kate being the one to spurn him when he begs her to accompany him on an adventure. So we've got a nice circle here: at 23:23:23 in Season 1 AND in Season 3 there's teary-eyed Jack, but the circumstances and even the characters are quite different. Which just goes to show: 1) Lost is awesome; and 2) Jack should really think about financing his trip back to the Island by buying some stock in the Kleenex company or something.

So it might just be me, but today totally feels like a holiday. All week I've been looking forward to today, and now something just seems...special about it, somehow. Maybe it's the thought that right now, all over the world, thousands (or even millions? Hundreds of thousands at any rate) are all sitting reading the same book. It's quite a beautiful thought, really, to be a part of something so huge and uniting. Just now, when I was coming back from getting my copy, this little girl comes tearing past me up the street, clutching her own copy. She obviously couldn't wait to get home and find out what happens -- and neither could I. Anyway, so I'm about 12 hours behind, but I just this minute got back from the bookshop with Deathly Hallows. I've also got a venti (which is so stupidly huge that I was embarassed to order it) London fog tea, and a pumpkin scone (not quite the same as a pumpkin pasty, but it will have to do). I am all set for a marathon reading session. It's funny, years ago when I first read Harry Potter, I thought ahead to when Book 7 might be published (& so far away did it seem) and thought that by then I might be living in London. I would be all grown up by then, I thought, and I pictured myself sitting on the Tube on my way to my exciting and glamourous job reading the final book. Well, I suppose I was very nearly living in London at this point, but nearly isn't the same as actually, and actually here I am exactly where I was those 7(?) years ago: still living in my parent's house, with the rest of the family away on holiday. I had planned to sit out in the garden to read, like I did with all the rest of the books, but the weather isn't cooperating. It's pouring rain out, which does seem strangely fitting somehow. The perfect day to curl up inside with a good book, at any rate. And very suitable that it's raining for The End. Like how it's always raining for funerals in movies. I am completely unspoiled, btw, and for the record, I don't think Harry's going to die. (Though I wouldn't be surprised if he did.) Some things I do think will happen: Dumbledore will come back in some way, shape, or form to help Harry. Snape will ultimately be good, and will die in the end. Neville and Ginny will have very important roles to play. And Neville or Ron will die. Which is very sad to me, as they're two of my favourite characters. But enough of all this: time to crack open that book and find out what happens at last!

Went to see Order of the Phoenix last night -- almost went to a midnight show on Tues. night, but no-one else was very bothered, and I was really tired, so the thought of staying up til 3am, then having my alarm go off at 6:30 the next morning was not that appealing. Still, I really must to the midnight show of at least one of the final two movies. (If only Australia would have a midnight show when it finally opens! Seems highly unlikely though) Anywho, I really liked it. Probably the second-best of the movies, after Prisoner of Azkaban. Although, it's a good thing I haven't read the book in over a year, because of all the things they left out. The scenes I most missed from the book were all the ones from the big Ministry of Magic battle -- the brains, the time-turners, and that. I can understand why they cut them out of the movie though, and I can appreciate that there's at least one movie this summer that knows less is more when it comes to emotional impact and keeping people's interest. Speaking of emotional impact though, WTF was up with Sirius's death? He's supposed to just get knocked off-balance and fall through a curtain -- NOT get Avadra-Kadavra-ed and then dissolve into some frakking mist. I suppose they felt they needed to make his death a bit more obvious, but I think it would've worked well the other way. As usual, the casting was brilliant: Imelda Staunton was simply marvellous as Umbridge, I reckon she's the best movie character to date. Luna was great as well. I'm only sorry that there isn't enough time to spend more with all these characters. (Another scene I would've loved to have seen in its entirety was Snape's Worst Memory. I'm glad they left it in, but it was like 30 seconds long! It just seemed a bit perfuntory here.) At least they gave Sirius a few good scenes before he snuffed it, even if movie!Sirius is a bit soppier than book!Sirius. Speaking of soppiness, I don't know what it is about these movies, but while I don't exactly burst into tears at them, I do tend to get very misty-eyed whenever there's the speech about the importance of love, and friendship and sacrifice and all that. I'm not usually a crier, but there's just something about it all that seems to get me. And moreso in the movies than the books, for some reason. I think here it was all the flashes of those things that we saw whilst Harry was possessed bu Voldemort: they really brought the idea home, in a very visceral and effective way that I think movies are better at than books. I mean, I love the HP books a lot more than the movies, because nothing beats them for immersion in this fantastical world, the details of everyday life, the access to the characters' intimate thoughts so we can understand them and watch them grow, but there are some things that the movies can do better. I think, actually, that that possession scene is a perfect example of how to translate a book scene into a movie scene. The problem with making OotP into a movie is that so much of the book is spent inside Harry's head as he's being a Horrible Teenager. Without the access to his thoughts the book allows, the movie has a big task in dramatising all this. I think they did an admirable job (in fact, I prefer this new screenwriter; I wish he were staying on for HBP, as his dialogue is also a lot sharper) although it would've come off even better with a stronger actor as Harry. As I type this, I've got the Jericho recap show on in the background -- I thought I should give it another chance, as I saw the first few eps last autumn & thought it was fairly silly, but when there was that whole hullaballoo when it was cancelled, I thought that maybe it got better. So far, "What's this black stuff?" "That used to be Denver." isn't really going to win me over. Granted, it's still on the beginning episodes, but so far all this is doing is reminding me how ridiculous it was: Daddy issues, pen (well, straw) tracheotomies, mysterious pasts, morally ambiguous character, food and water shortages -- remedied by supply drops from the sky --, love triangle -- I've seen this before, done much better -- and without the hokey small-town America vibe. Maybe I'm just bitter, because this is what I used to watch on Thursdays while waiting for the new ep of Lost to download, and that it was promoted (in Australia at least) with ads that made it seem like even more of a Lost clone than it did already. (The v/o would talk about 'the others' coming, the mysterious sickness, etc.) Plus, why the frak was this shown concurrently with the States when none of my favourite programmes were? ...okay, now they've gotten past the ridiculous 'radioactive rain' episode, so things are getting a bit more interesting, with these Others mercenaries. ...so, I suppose I'll give it a proper chance by watching a real episode, but still, I'm hardly riveted...something's missing...and I think that something is great characters. Because, when it comes down to it, that's what makes or breaks a tv show. Movies can get by with cardboard cutouts, because they're only an hour and a half or so long, and as long as there's sufficient amounts of action and explosions and generally cool stuff to look at, well, we can overlook a minor detail like a bland template of a hero/heroine/villain -- or even sidekick, as long as their jokes are funny enough, their one-liners quotable enough. But on a tv show, the characters must be interesting enough for us to want to spend time with them not just for an hour or two one night, but every single week, for years. Movies are about events, Big Things Happening; tv shows are about people's Everyday Lives. Family life, work life, social life; the characters are friends who phone every week to update us. In the case of shows like Lost, Battlestar Galactica, or, yes, Jericho, those lives are predicated around a Big Event: a plane crash, the genocide of the human race, atomic war -- but that is gotten over with in the first hour; it's the prologue not the climax. The remaining hundred or so hours we spend with these people is all about who they are, how the event will change them, how they will rebuild their lives. The decisions, and consequences, mistakes and triumphs, relationships and moral questions that they deal with every day as they struggle to rebuild their lives. So. The characters better be interesting, and the writing better be good if I'm going to care about any of this stuff enough to keep tuning in week after week a hundred times over. From what I've seen of Jericho so far, Our Hero is rather too bland for his Mysterious Background to seem very gripping. With his introduction as the prodigal son returning from parts unknown, it seems as though they're trying to make him into a sort of bad-boy anti-hero, but with his Daddy Issues and angst and romantic quandry between Girl Next Door and Temptress, he's stuck at just the traditional reluctant hero. Skeet Ulrich's lack of any real charisma, and his mostly one-dimensional portrayal don't really help, either. But, look at me, saying I'd give it a second chance, then bashing it for paragraphs. Blank slate, open mind, and I'll try again.

...so it's already been five weeks since the Lost finale. Only just over seven months left to go! I had wanted to wait for Season Three to come out on DVD sometime in August, but I just couldn't leave humanity enslaved by the Cylons on New Caprica for two months, not when I knew I could find out what happened with no waiting at all. There are drawbacks to watching a series all at once, but not having to wait for eight or nine frakking months after a cliffhanger is...would 'sublime' be too strong of a word? Unfortunately, now thanks to my impatience, I have to wait six months for the resolution to a much more shocking and dramatic cliffhanger. (OMGWTFCYLONS! STARBUCK?!) On the drawback front, watching a show that has long since aired means that spoilers are much harder to avoid -- despite my best efforts, I managed to accidently spoil myself for the time-jump, and, worse, Tigh and Anders. (Though not the less-shocking Chief & Tory) At least Starbuck's death(?) and return were a complete shock. -- Although, I was a bit worried about her as I had heard about Katee Sackoff being on the new Bionic Woman. Also a drawback (for me) with having all the episodes to watch at once is not having that week in-between to think things over and theorise. Way to cultivate an audience, networks. Sigh...whoever would've thought that the day would come when I'd miss summer reruns? Well, there is Doctor Who, which I've started watching...just downloaded the series w/ Christopher Eccleston to catch up with, but am loving David Tennant as the Doctor. This week's ep was particularly exciting, as they were standing in practically the exact spot I stood in at the Globe Theatre! Plus, I'm a sucker for time travel, so I'm really enjoying it. They manage to throw in just the right amount of past/present/future irony and jokes I think, without it becoming annoying. (Oh, Book 7, you can't get here fast enough!) 'Help Me.' OMGOMGOMGOMG, I can't believe it! I may say this all the time, but this time I really mean it: that HAS to be the most shocking end of a Lost episode, EVER. I TOTALLY did not see that coming, and I am seriously shaken by it. I mean, the 'you're all dead' ending a couple weeks ago was a great bit of WTFery, but for pure dramatic shock value, nothing tops this. The closest would be Michael killing Ana Lucia & Libby last year, but I NEVER thought they'd kill LOCKE. Although... Instant crazy theory of the week: Locke will be 'reborn'. Last week I said I thought he resembled Jesus carrying the cross (& thus, in hindsight, going to his death.) And goodness knows, this show has more than its fair share of Christ imagery. (& his mother's claim that he was 'immaculately conceived') We have only just seen a character return from the dead, and renewed evidence of the Island's miraculous healing powers with Naomi. The Island has already magically healed Locke once. It seems as though the Island can only heal if there's no interference (Mikail had to remove the branch from Naomi) but Locke was shot at close range; could the bullet have gone right through him? I'm thinking that we won't see him for a while, but he'll make a return, either at the end of the season finale, or next season. Evidence against? Well, Locke HAD just started being totally awesome again, and when people start being totally awesome, it's usually a sign of their impeding doom. And, well, Damon & Carlton DID say that once people were dead, they were really and truly dead. (until the zombie season!) And I was convinced that Libby would make a miraculous recovery too, but she snuffed it in the next episode. But, of course, Locke is a much more important character. And he seems to be the only one who can work the Island's magic. But, now that we know how he ended up in the wheelchair, is there much more of his story to tell, in flashbacks? But, that doesn't seem to have stopped them with Jack, or arguably many other characters as well... Okay, enough of this debate. Moving on... BEN. Wow, he really is well and truly EEEVIL. The more we've seen of him this season, the less threatening he's become. But now we see that not only did he murder his own father, he collaborated in the murder of dozens more innocent people, all to...get back at his BadDad? When they were sitting in the van, I totally called it that he would off his father, but I did not see the Dharma genocide coming. So that was the purge Mikail told us about, with the help of Ben, killed all the Dharmites, and moved in. Eventually, it seems, they became the people they killed, and then had a group of 'hostiles' of their own to deal with in our Losties. And now the Losties are planning a little purge of their own... The pigs are walking, indeed. But, as usual, more questions raised: did anyone else survive the purge? I wouldn't be surprised if there's a rebel group living in the hills, or somesuch. And what about Annie? Was she killed off too? Or will she magically appear at some point? How did Ben become leader? I'm guessing he was fairly young when all that went down (20?) and Alpert seemed to be the Hostile's leader. Who were the Hostiles in the first place? Obviously not the native inhabitants of the Island; they dressed in the same ragged 'dress up' clothes the Others used, but Richard was clean shaven, and wore an expensive-looking watch. Was that hut where they used to live? What happened in the intervening years? Was Ben's mother Smokey? Richard seemed very interested in weather she'd on the island or off... ARGH! SO MANY QUESTIONS! But poor little Harry Ben. I did feel bad for him, with no mother and his crap father. Speaking of which, interesting that he had such a lowly father, especially in contrast to so many of the Losties having rich and powerful fathers. More thoughts about Ben: -He is SUCH a liar. The Psych! opening totally got me, as they always do. I wonder what it is with Portland and the Others... So his mother died in childbirth, just like his Biblical namesake's. But I was kind of hoping that he and Locke would be twins, or at least brothers... -Ben's story had very interestng echoes of Kate - childhood best friend in love with, who gives present of great emotional value; goes home to drunken awful father & removes shoes; kills father - His mother has the same name as Locke's: Emily -Interesting parallel between Ben's killing of his father in order to join the hostiles, and Locke's inability to kill his father in order to join the Others. It really drives home the point that Locke is the 'anti-Ben': the good to Ben's evil, the white to his black. The Island healed Locke and made him walk again; it sickened Ben and left him crippled. How can a parallel this interesting be left unexplored? Locke has to live. -The Dharma caste system - a bit unusual for a 'utopian society', no? Ben's father was a 'Work Man', so Ben becomes one too. And the way everyone's job title was embroidered right beneath their name on all their clothes. -Ben's father being Roger Workman: LMFAO!!! After his badge was shown in the preview last week, I said, half-joking, 'just watch -- Roger will turn out to be Ben's father.' And then he did! Every time I saw him in his uniform, I LOLed. And who would have guessed that 'Tricia Tanaka Is Dead', The Happiest Lost Episode Ever, would have foreshadowed such a grim and pivotal event? -Little Ben's pet bunny!!! I LOLed. And he carried it in a messenger bag too. Damnit, Juliet & Jack are good...I think. It looks like the Others are turning against Ben. I thought last week that Richard giving Locke Sawyer's folder so Sawyer would kill Cooper was all part of Ben's master manipulation plan, but now it looks as though Ben DIDN'T want Locke to kill Cooper after all; he really did want to discredit him as he saw him as a threat to his power. And Juliet's flashcard video, which I'd doubted all along also seems to be real too. And, it seems that Ben really didn't want Locke to take that tape -- but then why was he so sloppy and obvious with it? Did he just really underestimate Locke, and believe that he truly was 'One of Them' now? At any rate, it seems that Ben is getting verrry desperate, and things are really falling apart for him. He is rapidly becoming more dangerous, and less Evil-Mastermind-like with the overly-elaborate schemes. Damn, damn, damn. I hate it when Jack is right. Random theory: Jack and Juliet were off recruiting Rousseau! That's why she came to get the dynamite! JACOB: WTF??? What was going on in that cabin? I was thinking that Ben was making him up when he started talking to the empty chair, but then there was all that crazy poltergeist stuff: was it all a show that Ben had rigged up, just in case? Or that someone else had rigged up to fool Ben? Or was it real? Because it seemed a little...lame. Like out of Scooby-Doo or something. At any rate, Ben was reeeaaalllly bringing the crazy in that scene: I think he believes Jacob is real. But what's gotten into Locke that he's suddenly laughing in Ben's face? All this kind of stuff seems like exactly what he would have been worshipping before. I wonder if something happened to him in the hatch implosion, to give him a deeper knowledge of the Island. Hopefully he will come back from the dead to let us know? And even though I'm sure many people will be crying foul that the big reveal of Jacob was that he is the Invisible Man, I am glad that he wasn't just someone we've already seen walking round the Island, like Jack's dad or something. And I never bought into the whole 'Richard Alpert is Jacob' theory. WHY DOESN'T RICHARD ALPERT SEEM TO AGE?????? Volcano - mentioned in school, then was that the river of ash Locke & Ben crossed? Might this be what wiped out the original inhabitants, the ones who built the ruins and the statue? The Hostiles killing the Dharmites with the gas cannisters. Surely this wasn't the same gas that they used on Kate and Jack? Because it seemed to kill them instantly. And Kate and Jack aren't dead. (Or are they?) Looking back though, that scene where they don gas masks and exit from the village does seem like a creepy reversal of the way they arrived there. At any rate, I really want to know what's going on with this whole 'You're all dead' business. SUCH a good episode, so much to think about. I think it was the perfect ratio of questions to answers. How can the episodes just keep getting better and better like this? Although, this week's was great in a very different way to last week's grown-up drama that was almost like a stand-alone play. (If I was in charge of picking an Emmy episode to submit, "The Brig" would be it.) This week was more Lost at its WTF, crazy-Island, vaguely-supernatural, mythological best. Both: A++

Just finished watching "The Brig" for the second time... First of all, WOW. Lost is really on an awesome streak at the moment; each episode is even better than the last. And this one...it was just so dense with references and symbolism, while still being all about the characters of Locke and Sawyer, and furthering the plot, all at the same time. I know a lot of people make fun of Damon and Carlton, but I really don't think there can be any disputing their talent as writers. I've always thought that one of the best-written and most well-constructed epidsodes of Lost is 'Deus Ex Machina', the first one they wrote together, but 'The Brig' has to rank right up there. (Interestingly, they've written the majority of the Locke episodes, but the upcoming finale will be their first Jack episode, except for the Season 2 & 3 premieres, which Damon wrote seemingly as a matter of course.) And backing up that brilliant writing was some absolutely wonderful acting -- Josh Holloway has really just shone this season, I hope he's up for the Emmy come September; Terry O'Quinn & Michael Emerson are reliably fantastic as ever -- and some good directing as well. That final scene with Sawyer and Cooper...there are no words. I was so emotionally involved, I didn't know whether I wanted Sawyer to kill him because he's so obviously the biggest bastard ever in the history of the world, or to forgive him instead. But in the end I was glad he killed him, because I don't want Sawyer to come to terms with his past, which of course = death on Craphole Island. But the obvious emotional toll it took on Sawyer was heartbreaking. The confrontation came at the worst possible time for him: he was finally starting to allow himself to relax and be a nice guy, to let himself be vulnerable, instead of being a dickhead all the time to protect himself. And, just when he's let his defences down, his past blindsides him. So I'm guess no more Mister Nice Gaius Sawyer for a while. Which I'm fine with. I'm totally fine with pretty much anything as long as they don't kill him off. Plus, it would be awesome if he told Kate to just smarten up and get the hell over Jack. Speaking of Kate...STFU, Kate. It's like anytime she's within a hundred meters of Jack she becomes this annoying, submissive, desperate, needy, suckup. Sigh. She's so much better when she's far away from Jack and goes back to being all kick-ass and awesome. If only Jack is one of the ones to die in the finale. But I'm sure it will instead be someone totally awesome, like Sayid. And speaking of Jack... I finally realised what's been different about him since he got back from Otherville: he's been Otherised. Gone are his crazy eyes, his Jackfaces, his shouting fits over nothing every episode, his over-reactions to everything, his charging off on thoughtless missions doomed to failure. Instead, he has the eriely calm demeanor all the Others have, with a friendly though unemotional response when people talk to him. Ooooh, I do hope he's been brainwashed or converted or SOMETHING interesting, because if he's still just regular old Jack, biding his time until he can put another stupid-ass plan into action? So, so lame, like: ha-ha! You, viewers, fell for Jack's Other act just like the simple, unsuspecting Losties did. They distrusted him, and they paid the price. It's just as well Super!Jack is a forgiving man, and has come to the rescue of all and sundry. Blargh. BUT, how happy am I that all the Losties (well, except, apparently, Kate) no longer trust him, and have finally seen the light and put their faith in Sayid. YES. Desmond is not only hot, he's also smart. As for Locke...interesting how, after being conned all his life, he manages to manipulate Sawyer into doing what he can't. He's obviously been watching Ben closely and taking notes. Because, so much manipulation still going on there. The whole thing with the tape player was clearly staged by Ben: he wanted Locke to have it, but why? I wonder if he might want the Losties to come to them, and by learning of an imminent attack they will make a pre-emptive strike. I just adore how overly-dramatic all his plans are: Cooper tied to a massive pillar? I was expecting Kong to appear out of the jungle and scoop him up. And there was a noticable lack of guns: Ben has taken Locke's words to heart -- though Sawyer's was conveniently out of bullets, forcing a much more dramatic and symbolic kill. And Locke struggling through the jungle at the end, under the weight of his father's body: I got a distinct 'Jesus bearing the cross' vibe from that shot. So, Cooper thinks they're in Hell? (Although, a pirate ship in the middle of the jungle sounds more like Disneyland than Hell to me :P) Makes sense: 'We know ALL your sins...'(And doesn't this sound just like Benry? 'Ah, my ridiculously circuitous plan is one-quarter complete...') Although, seriously, while I'm (pretty) sure it's not Hell, this is the second recent conspicuous statement that the Island is not what they think. Not to mention the 4,815,162,342 various other hints. I really have no idea where they're going with this, but I'm def enjoying the ride. CAN'T WAIT FOR NEXT WEEK, OMFG!!! BENRY FLASHBACK!!! WHO IS JACOB??? (I think it's really Benry, he just made Jacob up to keep his minions in line) And I can't wait for Juliet to be revealed as the mole she is...

Kate and Claire telling Sun about the medical hatch; Charlie & Hurley revealing that Kate told them about The Flame, and Patchy, Kate telling Sun what Jack said about his time with the Others, and what Juliet said about pregnancies. Oh -- and because I'm in full-on nerd mode at the moment? Battlestar Galactica Season 2 marathon this weekend!

The moral of this week's episode: Sayid is always right. Jack is always wrong. Oh, how I wish Locke hadn't blown up that submarine so Jack could have left. (But, the look on Sawyer's face when Jack said that he had been going to leave, LOL) And Sayid is totally my hero, the way he lists all the things he wants Juliet to tell him -- basically, half the things the audience is dying to find out. I don't need to ask her any questions because I saw in her eyes that she wants to leave, and that is all I need to know, ever.' Argh, what a DUMBASS. I seriously hope he is working with Juliet and/or the Others in some way, or has been brainwashed, or SOMETHING, because otherwise he is just the stupidest person EVER. And supposedly we have to sit through ANOTHER of his flashbacks in a few weeks. Unless it reveals that his dad is actually Jacob, or something like that. Speaking of Jacob, he seems to have been upgraded from the Others' leader to their god. What with the way Ben spoke of him to Juliet, you could hear the capital-H 'He', and then all of the 'Do you doubt Jacob' business Ben was spouting. Creepier and creepier. Before I get to the main point of my entry, I just want to say: Holy. Frack. I finally decided to see what all the hype was about and watch Battlestar Galactica. I've had a Season 1 marathon this long weekend, just finished 'Kobol's Last Gleaming, Part 2' two minutes ago, and I am officially hooked. Commander Adama staged a coup then was shot by Boomer who just found out she is a Cylon! Dr Gaius has a Cylon baby! Apollo realised that as a central male character of a television drama series he really ought to have more Daddy Issues, and betrayed his father! Various other exciting things are happening back on Caprica involving Starbuck kicking Cylon ass and pregnant Cylons and prophetic arrows that may save humanity from extinction! And back on mythical Earth, I apparently can't get hooked on a t.v. show that I can talk about without sounding like the world's biggest nerd! (More on this later.) Right. Now that I've gotten that somewhat out of my system, on to what I was originally going to say. Which is totally unrelated, and is: sometime back around October/November, I had one of my periodic panics about my life going nowhere, and there I was arsing around Australia spending all my hard-earned savings, and where I nothing I did really mattered in the long run because my visa expired in a few months anyways. So after doing a lot of research for probably the first time ever, I came up with a plan. My plan was basically, Be Kind, Rewind. I would head back home, with a week or two's holiday in London and Edinburgh on the way, get my old job back, and sign up for night classes at a local university so as to actually get some sort of qualification that might be somewhat useful when it came to getting a real job. And what do you know. That plan, out of all my plans -- was a success. Perhaps a little too much so. Once I set things in motion, evrything just fell into place. I wrote a tenative email to my old boss to see what the situation there was, and she wrote back to say that just that very day put out an ad to hire a new person, and that I was more than welcome back. I changed my flight to London to late January, and after Christmas I told I my Australian job and my landlady that I was leaving. I got in touch with the English relatives and arranged to stay with them. I got in touch with my friend in Edinbrgh, and arranged to visit her. I booked the train up to Edinburgh, and my flight home from London and before I knew what was going on, everything was set in motion, and it was too late to change my mind. I was able to continue in my Australian job until a few days before I left, so I had lots of money, and I tried to make the most of time I had left in Melbourne to do all the things that I'd been meaning to do. (Though I did have an absolutely wonderful and useless Christmas week when I was on holiday, and the weather was awful so I stayed inside, sitting by the heater eating decadent Christmas food and working my way through Season 2 of Lost and House, only venturing out to see about 4 or 5 movies in less than a week.) But then all of a sudden it was the day I was leaving, a beautiful warm sunny day in January, and I was walking to the post office in the morning, and all I could think of was how much I didn't want to leave. Because while Australia had been tough going, there had been a lot more good moments than bad, and I finally felt as though I was getting somewhere. I just had to keep reminding myself that it would all have been over in a few months in any case. So off I flew to London, where I had an absolutely wonderful almost-two weeks there and in Edinburgh, getting to pretend I was a student again. (only this time with money!) Back down in London, I treated myself to a luxury hotel (which I got for 1/4 of the real price!) and three shows in two days. I ate lunch outside in Covent Garden, and shopped til I dropped (much to my later regret when it came time to weigh my suitcase at the airport). And then...and then I was back home, and back to work two days later, and before the end of the week it was like I had never left. Just like I had wanted. Only now, a large part of me wished I was back in sunny Australia, working for the proper company that paid better, and going sightseeing on the weekends, and all the problems were completely forgotten. As usual, Oscar Wilde got it right when he said, 'There are only two tragedies in life. One is not getting what one wants; the other is getting it.'

...well, technically it's the equivilant of June in the Northern Hemisphere, but as 'Christmas in June' isn't a saying, I'm going with 'July'. Anyways, my point is that this is so weird. I mean, here it is, 7pm on Christmas Eve, and not only is it still light out, I'm wearing a short-sleeved top and sandals, spent an hour earlier sitting outside reading-- and it's actually a 'cold day' (ie, somewhere around 20). I was actually hoping for a really hot Christmas Day just for the contrast of it, but it's apparently going to be the coldest for 60 years. Typical. So, needless to say, it doesn't feel the slightest bit like Christmas. After a failed attempt at the beginning of the month to feel Christmas-y, I gave up, but yesterday I decided to give it another go, as I was officially on a week's holidays. Oh-- and the office Christmas party on Friday? A picnic! Luckily there are several English people who work there as well, so I wasn't the only one excited about the novelty of it all. Though as Friday was a really hot day, and everyone was doing random bits of work in a mad rush to finish everything up, it totally had a 'last day of school' feel to it, which I guess is at least a holiday of sorts. Anyways, yesterday I headed into the city to do my Christmas shopping (last-minute as ever) & had a lovely time wandering through all the fantastic arcades. After I'd actually managed to find some nice presents, I thought I would brave the ignomity of Starbucks in Australia to have my annual Eggnog Latte. Only to find that they don't actually make them here, which seems a bit dumb. I suppose it's because Australians (well, Melbournians at least) are such dreadful coffee snobs. It can't be because they don't have eggnog here-- I know they do because I've seen in in the supermarket. Anyways, I settled for a Peppermint something-or-other Frappucino, and sat outside in the sun drinking it, looking at the huge Christmas tree & listening to a band somewhere play Christmas music. It was all very surreal. You know, even though Australia's pretty much as far away as you can get, it really doesn't feel that way-- except for moments like that. But on the whole, Australia doesn't seem to go in for Christmas as much as the northern countries, I'm guessing because it sort of blends with summer. I've hardly heard any Christmas music, decorations seem to be largely a token effort, and there's only been a couple Christmas movies on TV. It's all a bit disappointing, really, cause Christmas is usually a highlight of the year, and such a big, exciting event. So tonight, instead of the traditional port & mince pies by the fire with Christmas carols playing, I'm going out for drinks with J and some friends. Not very Christmas-y, but should hopefully be a nice night out. Then tomorrow I'm going round for Christmas lunch with her extended family, which I'm very glad they took pity on me & invited me to, as Christmas dinner by myself would be sadder than sad indeed. So that at least should be Christmas-y, as they have a real Christmas tree, and hopefully also crackers and Chrismas pud and all of that. And I will finally get to open my pressies in the morning, which arrived from my parents 6 weeks ago, and have been sitting, faithfully unopened, on my bookshelf ever since. (can you believe how good I was not to have cheated, esp considering no-one would ever have known if I'd opened them early?) I just hope that the big parcel is big enough to be both DVDs of Lost and House seasons 2. Because I've been looking forward to some Christmas Day viewing of season 2 Lost eps for ages now, and purposefully timed my rewatching of season 1 of both shows to finsh this week. But I'm sure Mum & Dad came through for me.

And, it seems that after five loooong years, he's finally going ahead with a new movie, called...drumroll, please...Australia... ...would you like some wine to go with that cheese corn, Baz? Seriously, though, when I first heard him say that, my immediate thought was that he was joking. Then he went into one of his famous explanations, and he's almost won me over - because, my God, if ever there was someone who could sell his ideas, it's Baz. I mean, I understand where he's coming from with this title - film history, metaphor, grand scale, etc. - but I'm just picturing myself at the box office opening night, going 'one ticket for Australia please,' and the clueless teenager working there going, 'um, the travel agent's two shops down on the left.' Oh, who am I kidding? By next week I'll be passionately defending it to friends & family, with a dozen good reasons why it's completely perfect & utterly genius. But, wait a minute: 'heard him say?' I (don't) hear you asking? How did this come about? Well, for once in my life I was watching tv at the right moment. This very am, as I glumly ate breakfast with the morning show chattering inanely away unheeded on the telly, I happened to glance up as the words 'latest Australian epic' were scrolling off the bottom of the screen. 'Surely they couldn't mean Baz will be on?' I thought. But, they did! And, even better, he would be on at 8:10, meaning I would have just enough time to watch before I had to leave for work. After I recovered from choking on my museli, I got ready in record time, so as to be perched on the edge of my seat by 8:10, super-excited be watching what must be a world exclusive. I spent all day thinking about how lucky I was to be in Australia, because surely I would never get to see this back in Canada - only to arrive home, and find the interview posted, in its entirety, on Nine's website. Damn. Some more thoughts: 1. I love Australia - check out those identifiers (or whatever the actual term is) on the screen: 'Oscar-nominated Director' and 'Legendary Director'. They even corrected history so Baz got what he deserved. 2. Blunnies! Hee, Baz wearing Blundstone boots with his suit totally cracked me up. Obviously he wore them to accentuate his 'Australian-ness', in the rugged outback sense, but worn with a suit, and while sitting for a television interview, they carried the slightest whiff of pretentiousness with them. (And, to accentuate his 'artiness', the unbuttoned collar & loosened tie.) Don't worry Baz, I love you for always looking the part. 3. Who is this mysterious third actor? I've been wracking my brain all day. I assume he'll play the third corner in the love triangle I've read about, which would put him age-wise in his 30s to 40s. He's Australian. And it sounds like he's well-known. Russell's out, obviously. There've been rumours of Heath Ledger, but he was supposed to be out as well - and, he seems perhaps slightly young? I just wish we knew more about the plot. It sounds like the husband might not be dead after all, or maybe like he dies at the cattle station? Because he would make an obvious third corner: the uptight, upper-class Englishman, representing the past. Fair, and with a finer build to contrast with Hugh, he would be a bit of a dandy perhaps, and completely out-of-touch with the land, thinking himself, and English society far superior. But then maybe there'll be more of an actual emotional choice involved for Nicole's character, with both men having both virtues and flaws. Oh, I don't know. All I know is that it sounds awesome, and I can't wait. Though of course I'll have to-- filming for 5 months starting in March takes until August, so odds of a Christmas 2007 release seem slim to none. Summer 2008 is possible, but I'm hoping the studio will see this as a prime Oscar contender, and thus hold onto it until the autumn, so my guess for a release date is... November 2008?! Sigh. It's already been over 5 years since MR, and I was just thinking the other day that it was this time ten years ago that I went to see R + J. I know genius takes time, but this is getting ridiculous! 4. 'The Chanel commercial's been getting a real flogging lately.' HAS IT? WHERE? Why is there a global conspiracy to prevent me from seeing the damn thing anywhere other than YouTube? (Swoon. Oh Rodrigo, why must you be so useless & annoying on Lost?) I had hopes last weekend when I went to see The Prestige, as I've noticed new Chanel No. 5 print ads with Nicole, and that seemed like the sort of film they might show it before, but no such luck. Also, interesting, how Baz seemed to go on the defensive about the cost of it, and then was quick to switch to talking about benefits to the Australian film industry. It seemed as though he might've had a fair bit of criticism in that area, but I haven't really aware of any. Anyways, I can only assume this completely unexpected (& somewhat random) appearance by Baz signals the official beginning of his new film *ahem*Australia, and hope that after years of nothingness, his official site will finally be open for business, perhaps with lots of behind-the-scenes goodies?

...was where I was this past Saturday. It was Melbourne Cup Carnival last week, which, while previously unknown to me, is a huge deal here. The day of the biggest race is even a public holiday, about which I have to say: a) only in Australia would people be given a paid day off work to, basically, drink lots and gamble; and b) total genius! I ended up up going to Stakes Day, the last day of it all, but it turned out to be the best day to go, because the weather was absolutely gorgeous-- unlike Tuesday, the holiday, when it was absolutely freezing. It was all a bit last-minute, so I ended up having to go shopping after work on Friday to buy an outfit meaning I was rather limited in time & selection. Still, I decided to go all out, and damn the expense! (well, to an extent) I've been looking for an excuse to buy a nice dress for ages now, and I figured, how often do I get a chance to get really & truely frocked up? As a result, I actually was excited about shopping for the first time in a long time. I had lots of fun trying on dresses and turning piroettes in the fitting room to make the skirts twirl out. That is, until the zipper got stuck on one dress whilst I was trying to take it off, so I got stuck with it over my head for five minutes as I panicked and only managed to get the zipper more stuck. I managed to get it off eventually, of course, and funnily enough that's the one I ended up getting. (Well, not that particular one-- I snuck that one back onto the rack, and swapped it for one with a non-broken zipper) So I ended up with a gorgeous dress (that cost way too much money), fabulous shoes, a cute little clutch, a necklace, and, to top it all off, a veddy proper hat! These are the posh people's races, you see, and that's what one wears. I felt pretty funny sitting there on the train dressed up like that though! (oh dear - could this paragraph sound any ditzier?) Anywho, the races themselves were heaps of fun. We drank champagne, ate sushi, and lost money betting on the losing horses. (well, I did. S got to shout and jump up and down as his horse came from behind to win.) I didn't really care though, I was just thrilled to be there. (lol, really!) I mean, this is just the sort of thing that I read about in newspapers or magazines and wish I could go to, but never get the chance. Well, after that glimpse of how the other half lives, it came as a rather unpleasant shock on Monday morning to be rudely awoken by my alarm and have to get up, put on boring work clothes, bolt my breakfast, and run for the train in the rain. I was in a foul mood all day, completely hating work, and seriously ready to throw in the towel. Today, however, I was feeling very much improved-- helped, too, by getting to have free fancy cake in the afternoon as it was someone's birthday at work, and also by the fact that I was trusted enough to take the company car (!) and go to the bank by myself.
