Speaking of good moods & iPods (& Hugh Laurie, of course): House returns tomorrow! Huzzah!

Well, I have finally gotten a better temporary job, only to immediately start loathing having to get up early, and wishing that I could go back to being unemployed and bored. I don't know what it is about me, but whatever I have, I always want the opposite. I know that as soon as I don't have a job to go to, I'll go right back to wishing I did. So what do I want?! Anyways, I'm back at the second job I had here, so obviously the only reason I got it was because I'd been there before. Sigh-- even with temp work, it seems that it's not what you know, but who you know. They originally wanted me only for Tues & Weds, which I thought sounded perfect: I'd earn enough to cover another week's expenses, but still have Thursday free to sleep in and watch Lost in the arvo whilst eating my new favourite lunch of a grilled cheese sandwich. These last two actions are now seemingly inextricably linked in my strange brain, due to the fact that I was really hungry when I watched the premiere of Lost, and so the grilled cheese that Juliet brought to Jack looked extra-good, with the result that once the ep had finished, I went and made myself one, and have eaten them for lunch every day since. (I have this weird thing where I always get cravings for whatever food people are eating in movies or tv shows. I once walked all over the city looking for a nice noodle place after watching a movie where the characters were eating noodles.) Anyway, the point of this extremely long digression is that when I was asked to stay on & work an extra day, the fact that I wouldn't get to do this flashed across my mind. Luckily, common sense (& greed) won out, so I ended up working Thursday, then Friday, and they've asked me to go back on Mon and Tues as well. I agreed, with inner reluctance. As long as I have Wed and Thurs free for the return of House, and Lost ;) To be fair though, my dislike for working is not entirely (or even, I would like to think, mostly) due to television-related reasons, but mainly because the work is so mind-numbingly boring. I mean, I complained about my real job at home, but I also never woke up and didn't want to go to work, which is exactly what's happening every morning here. I guess it comes down to the fact that for all its problems, my real job had advantages as well. Nice people to talk to all day. Being able to spend large amounts of time checking my email, and reading about tv shows, movies, and other entirely un-work-related subjects on the internet. Paid lunches and longer-than-usual breaks. The truth is-- and I never thought I'd say this in a million years-- I really miss it. So much so that I'm seriously contemplating going back. That is, if they'll take me back. If only my replacement would quit in the new year, so I could go back and pick up where I left off. (With the addition of some night classes, so I could get a better job at some point. Because, whilst I'm nostalgic, I'm not completely deluded.) In the mean time, I'll just go back to trying to figure out the time difference right now (daylight savings has me extra-confused) so I'll know when I'll be able to watch Hugh Laurie on SNL. And hope that they let him write some scenes, because the last time I tuned into SNL it was so dismally unfunny it was embarassing. And I hate having to watch actors I like do unintentionally embarassing things. I just hope they don't make his monologue all about how 'Guess what?! He's actually English!!!! OMGWTFPolarbear!!' Because that got old about 2 years ago. On the plus side, he's apparently both singing AND 'dragging up', which would seem to bode well.

...okay, so this time I'm totally serious about going back to updating my LJ at least semi-regularly... Well, we'll see how we go. I am, at least, back to being unemployed, with my own internet-enabled computer, which is a step in the right direction. Or, not. But hey, at least I'm bored, unemployed and poor in an exotic foreign country! So, this Australia thing doesn't seem to be working out quite as well as I'd hoped, in other words. I mean, Melbourne's a great city, and I'm totally loving the fact that it's summer here (well, technically still spring, but I call this summer weather. It was 36 degrees the other day. I don't think Vancouver's ever been that hot!) but autumn at home. Although, it does tend to make me feel strangely out-of-time, speaking to my parents having Thanksgiving dinner whilst I'm sitting there in a sundress. But, yes. It turns out that my fears of being just as unemployable in Australia as I am at home have, sadly, turned out to be totally justified. Add to that the fact that looking for a place to live-- which I had thought would be a total walk in the park-- was actually a long, drawn-out soul-destroying nightmare of making phonecall after phonecall only to be told that the room was no longer available, then when I did manage to get a viewing, wandering lost round the Melbourne streets-- usually at night-- searching for houses, only to get there and find a dark, dirty, depressing dump of a house inhabited by strange people. (I'm exaggerating here, but not by much.) The few decent houses I did manage to find, the people living there always picked someone else, and the one house where they did pick me, there was a huge drama with the estate agent which resulted in my application being denied because I had no job. All this time, I was living in a hostel, which, while the nicest one I'd ever stayed in, was still a hostel. So, at this point -- mid-to-late August I was very close to packing it all in and going home.Fortunately, it was the darkness before the dawn, & things managed to work out for the best, as, with the help of J, I managed to find a nice house that was not dark, dirty & depressing, but bright, clean, and cheerful. With normal people living in it. And no popularity contests to win or beastly estate agents to be approved by before I could move in. So at this point, I thought, 'right, things are finally turning around for me here.' I'd just signed on with a temp agency for work, and everyone I'd spoken too had said how the agencies had just heaps of work, I wouldn't have time for it all. So I moved in to my new house, finally unpacked everything, and sat back and waited for the work to start flooding in. And waited. And waited. (Note to self: People LIE. Or, they don't mean to lie, but the rules which apply to them don't, for some reason, seem to apply to you.) No work appeared, and my savings were dwindling, as were my fantasies of all the nice things I could buy for myself once the money started rolling in. At last, the call came. (hee, I love saying that, it sounds so dramatic!) It was quite dramatic as well, because they called at 10am, and wanted me to start asap. So, I lept out of bed and got all dressed up in my new suit, which I was so excited to wear-- with the heels and tights and everything, the overall effect was very, 'take a letter, Miss Smith'-- and dashed off to the train station. Standing on the platform I suddenly thought that here I was, fufulling my teenage ideas of being a proper grown-up going to work, standing there waiting for the train in my suit. The thing was, I didn't feel like a proper grown-up at all, more like I was playing dress-up. I certainly felt strange dressed like that, like an impostor, partucularly when I caught sight of my reflection in a shop window. An hour and half and two train rides later, I was no longer feeling very grown up or sophisticated at all. I just felt lost and panic-y. Like so many things in my life, this had ended/begun with me dashing round, completely lost and increasingly late. In my haste to catch the train, I had only given the map on the computer a cursory glance before I dashed out the door, and so when I exited the train station and confidently set out in the direction I thought the office was in, I was dead wrong, and spent over an hour getting progressively more lost in the hot sun, and as my wrong turns had taken me to the middle of a residential neighbourhood, there was no-one around to point me in the right direction. I didn't even have the number so I could call for directions. Finally, when I almost 2 hours late, and on the verge of giving up, I finally stumbled on the right street. Luckily, my supervisor was very understanding about it. Anyways, that job was only two days, but a couple days later I got another that lasted for six days (& I managed not to get lost on my way there), so it seemed as though business had finally picked up. But the week after that, I only had one day of work, so I thought that perhaps I had better renew my online search for slightly longer-term jobs. After some inner debate, I applied for a job that went until the end of the year, in a mailroom, as I decided I couldn't afford to be too picky. It was through an agency, and they called me the next morning to go in for an interview. I had a bad feeling as soon as I walked into the office. It was hard to put my finger on exactly what, but something seemed a little off. It might have been a combination of the slightly worn though over-enthusiastic decoration, and the other people waiting in the reception area, most of whom were older and slightly strange looking, in the way that older people with temporary menial jobs tend to be. (oh dear, that totally makes me sound like a terrible snob...) So, it turned out that the job was only 4-6 hours a day, not full-time, but at least it was every day. So I though I'd better take it, at least until something better turned up. But when they called to confirm my start time, it turned out that it wasn't every day, just when the company needed extra help. And when I went in for the first day, it turned out that it was just 4 hours every day, no extra. Three weeks later, and I've had six half-days of work. So much for that idea. I'm now thinking that I might to go home much earlier than planned if something longer-term doesn't show up, because I'm just not making enough money. And I'm starting to go a little crazy with nothing to do all day. Well, I'll just have to see how it goes. Maybe with summer and the holidays coming up, there'll be more temp work available as people take more holidays. Speaking of holidays, after all this whinging I almost forgot to mention how fantastic my month-long holiday round Oz with J, U, and V was back in July. It was great to meet up with the girls again and catch up with everything. As always seems to happen when we get together, we had some crazy times, particularly as we left civilised Melbourne and Sydney behind and drove up into wacky Queensland. Man, there are some weird towns and people up there. We'd rented a car for 3 days, so we could see some more out-of-the-way places, but it turned out we'd vastly underestimated the distance we'd need to cover, so there was a lot more time spent driving each day than we'd planned, in order to get from Byron Bay up to the Whitsundays in time. But we got to see country towns when we stopped for the night, and for meals, and whilst I was very impressed by how they were unspoiled by rampant development and big-box stores, they did have an unmissable aura of strangeness about them. Maybe something to do with being so isolated. Then, the island we stayed on in the Whitsundays was extremely undeveloped (there were no roads or anything, just the run-down resort where we were staying), and also had a very strange aura to it. Walking around one day, we all agreed that it had a sort of Lost/Jurassic Park/Evil Genius Lair feel to it, like we were about to stumble upon some dastardly secret experiment. There was even a mysterious cable coming out of the ocean and running across the beach into the jungle. I was going to follow it to see if it led to a crazy Frenchwoman's underground home, but I was wearing flip-flops and was frightened of all the deadly Australian snakes and spiders, so decided that it was better to just pretend that it did. Anyways, the rest of the trip was mostly your typical tourist stuff, but it was heaps of fun, and we saw some amazing things: all the sights in Sydney, Byron Bay, snorkeling on the Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree Rainforest, Uluru, and lots more. In fact, I had such a great time and was so busy that I didn't see a single movie for the whole month of July. I have made up for this since, of course, what with being mostly unemployed and all, but that's the longest I've gone without feeding my cinema addiction since I started uni lo these many years ago.

As it's been so long since I updated, I thought I'd catch up over several entries, rather than my usual single ginormous entry. The reason I haven't updated for so long is primarily laziness, mixed with being back home and therefore having to use the family computer in the kitchen where everyone can see what I'm doing (or so I feel; my mother insists I'm paranoid & no-one is looking over my shoulder. Don't tell her, but she's probably right.) However, now I have finally successfully (more-or-less, anyways) manouvered the soul-destroying process which is more commonly known by the name of 'job hunting' with the end result that I now spend 8 hours a day, 5 days a week in front of a computer, and (since the novelty of actually having a job is quickly wearing off) am searching for ways to distract myself from said job while still maintaining the illusion of working, I forsee a return to frequent updates.

But enough of this: let's return to late April, and my surprisingly difficult farewell to Kingston & university...

<center>*Insert "wobble-glass" effect here*</center>
I managed to survive my remaining exams, despite having to fight off plagues of fruit flies to get to them-- no joke, every time I ran my hands through my hair during the exams, my desk would become littered with their tiny carcasses. Prehaps they were a punishment for my deadly sin of sloth-- I did not, needless to say, spend the whole time swotting madly. But I did alright, somehow, & my reward is a lovely degree which I cannot read, it being in Latin (the extent of my Latin being pretty much 'carpe diem' & 'caveat emptor') & which is now rolled up in its mailing tube on the dining room sideboard.

The moving-out business was its usual highly stressful near-disaster. I managed to sell most of my stuff, only to have the extremely spacey girl who was going to buy my bed (& whom I had stupidly said could pay me when she came to pick it up) pull a no-show, then e-mail me some incredibly feeble excuse. So duped out of $90, I had no choice at this point other than putting it out with the rest of my random bits for the Salvation Army to pick up. I would have been angry, but I was beyond caring by this point. Then there was my near panic attack, when I got into a cab with 2 huge bags of stuff to send home on a Greyhound bus in an attempt to avoid paying excess baggage fees, & when I told the driver my destination was the shipping depot he replied that had closed down. To cut a long & panicked story short, it turned out that it had just moved down the road into the main bus station, so I was able to send my stuff off.

All this-- packing, shipping, & selling-- was happing on the day before I left, in the rain, & by the evening I was completely knackered & collapsed in a heap on my suitcase in the middle of my empty room. But I managed to pull myself together enough for a farewell dinner with Maggie at Le Chien Noir-- the same bistro my mother & I eaten at the very first night I spent in Kingston--as I thought it would lend a lovely sense of closure to things.

We had planned to go out for breakfast the next morning too, but in the frantic last-minute rush, completely ran out of time. And so, before I knew it, I was sitting on an aeroplane watching Kingston disappear beneath me.(& I was sitting next to a Scottish man going to Scotland, so I thought was a neat summing-up of my entire 4 years at uni.) And I must say, despite all my complaining about Kingston over the years, I was not a little sad to see it fade into the distance. It was, after all, a siginifigant part of my life, I had a lot of memories there, & in the last year had finally 'come to terms' with it, as it were, discovering some nice places there. (I especially miss the video store down the street, which was the best & nicest I've ever been in)

And so, 10 months to the day I'd arrived home from Edinburgh, I was back home again, still not entirely sure I wanted to be there, & still without much choice in the matter. The difference was, this time I would HAVE to find a job, as I had my entire life before me, an utter blank, and a rapidly creeping panic of what on earth was I going to do next...

...because mine on Thursday wasn't the absolute and complete utter torture that I thought it would be, particularly when I realised that in the last 2 years I have written exactly 1 exam, and that was 10 months ago, so my exam-taking skills, rather questionable at the best of times, were bound to be a bit rusty, to say the least. This was also my literary criticism exam, the one I was dreading the most as is all bizarre abstract theories which are impossibly dense, and which I am supposed to understand at 8:30 in the morning not having read the article the night before because it was so boring it put me to sleep. That is, on those occaisions when I actually made it to class, which became increasingly rare as the year dragged on, and my immunity to my alarm clock grew alarmingly (harhar). At any rate, it's all over now, and I managed to write a decent amount on all the questions before time ran out, so I don't think I bungled it too badly. Essay writing, on the other hand, is not the least like riding a bike. It is like... well, it's like something which the more you do it, the worse you get at it. Which perhaps isn't like anything else at all, because I can't think of anything like that. It's just that, when I look back at the essays I wrote in high school, they all seem to have been better thought out, better structured, and just generally better than the ones I'm writing now. (though perhaps that's just my bad memory?) My take-home exam essays for Art History, which were due Thursday I just turned in this afternoon, having finished them this morning. Ooops. Anyways, thank Baz that's the last essay I have to write, ever, for my entire life (fingers crossed!), so hurrah with brass knobs on!!! Not a moment too soon is all I have to say about that. I'm sure that if I had another year at uni I would completely fail everything. Usually the desperation I need to write an essay kicks in at least the day before it's due, but this last term it hasn't seemed to kick in until after the blasted thing's due, if at all... Well, enough of that. I've an entire week of freedom before my next exam and it's a beautiful, sunny, warm day (warm enough for sandals, short sleeves & bare legs!) which I celebrated by walking round to the ice cream shop this afternoon. I must make the most of this before I head home in two weeks and will have Mater & Pater breathing down my neck until I find a job. Oh, and just because no week's complete without a bit of drama: the insanely frightening gigantic unidentifiable bugs with about 6 million legs, including an especially huge back pair, are back. I was in bed last night watching a DVD, & as I reached for my cup of tea, out of the corner of my eye I noticed something on the wall. Upon (slightly) closer inspection, this something was reavealed to be one of those terrifying insects. So I did what any sane person would do: I screamed and ran out of the room, scaring the life out of my flatmate who was watching tv in the living room. Anyway, I enlisted her help, and the two of us went back to capture the beast...only to find that it had vanished. Well, there was no way I was going to bed with this thing on the loose, so we tore apart my bedroom looking for it before it finally skittered back into view and I was able to capture it in a glass, then throw the whole thing off the balcony. No sign of any since, fortunately, *knocks on wood* but I'm still a bit twitchy. These are seriously frightening bugs, and I have never seen them anywhere before, I have no idea what they are, nor do I particularly want to. Just when I was starting to feel quite warmly about Kingston, & was getting a bit sad about leaving forever, this happens, & now I can't wait to leave & be as far away from these things as poss!

I was quite proud of myself this am though, as I did get up at 9:30, had a shower, then went out to buy a pain ay chocolat, cafe au lait, & strawberries for breakfast. ...and is now huddled in a heap in the corner quietly having a nervous breakdown. (yes, it's time again for another whingy self-indulgent post about the horrible stress/stressful horror of uni...) I have come to the conclusion that essays & exams were invented with the sole purpose of making uni so unpleasant as to drive students out into the real world & actual jobs. If it weren't for essays et al, I know I would probably be sticking around at uni (although one somewhere a bit more exciting) for a few more years, not having to work, sponging off of the government & my parents, sleeping in, having most of the day to spend as I please-- going to the coffee shop, going to the movies, reading, watching tv, on the computer, etc-- then just spending a few hours a day having a nice discussion about books & other interesting stuff. It's just the essays that ruin everything-- they're always hanging over my head so I can't enjoy things, then I inevitably wind up spending a simply agonised & torturous evening/night writing the damn things, plunging into an abyss of depression where I feel as though I'm stuck in some sort of unending hell & will never be happy again... (oh, the angst!) Anyways, I know I bring it all on myself, which is all the worse really cause I simply can't seem to do it the 'proper way' w/ stress-free weeks of preperation & research. Ah well, only 2 more to write (plus a take-home exam, plus 4 actual exams...) and then I'm free forever! So, the job interview from Tues. Didn't happen because I could not find the guy's office. Seriously. I looked for almost 1/2 hour too & just had to give up in the end-- how pathetic am I? Lol... Well, first of all while I'm waiting at the bus stop I realise I've forgotten the piece of paper with the actual address/room number on it. But if I go back to get it, then I'll miss the bus & be really late, so I figure I can sort it out when I get there, as I can remember the building name, and there must be a directory there, right? So anyways, I manage to get off the bus at the right stop (off to a good start!) & luckily the building's right there. I go in, and sure enough, there's a big directory in the lobby, and there's the name of the man I have the interview with, and his office number. Excellent. And I've still got 15 mins before 4, so I go for a walk around the building, then come back and set off down the corridor to find his office, which according to the directory is on the main floor. Only problem is, there don't really seem to be many offices along this hallway, and not many room numbers either. On my second pass, I find a door with the right number, kind of tucked away in a little alcove. But there's no nameplate or anything, and it's shut, looking pretty deserted. So I knock, and there's no answer. Thinking that maybe it's a back entrance or something, I head off down another corridor to try & find another door, and end up getting totally lost, eventually coming back out where I started. To make matters worse, it's this huge building that's almost totally deserted, and I'm wearing boots that make clicking noises that echo around as I walk. After some more aimless wandering, I come across a tiny room with a sign that says "general inquiries", and there's a couple of women in there, so I ask them where this office is, and one directs me just around the corner, to this little cluster of offices. But when I go in there, none of the doors have the right name on them. After getting lost again, I find my way back to the office, and the same woman this time actually escorts me to the cluster-- where I still cannot find the office. At this point, a woman whose out-of-the-way office I've walked past at least 3 times finally asks me who I'm looking for. "Oh, his office is just 3 doors down," she says. So I walk 3 doors down, but that office is shut & has a completely different name on the door. "Er-- this one?" I ask. "With this name on the door?" "Yes, that's right," she says in a manner that suggests I'm a total idiot. Just as I'm wondering if I've wandered into some sort of weird twilight zone, she suddenly turns back to me. "Just a minute, which M did you say you were looking for?" It turns out that everyone who'd been giving me directions apparently had stopped listening after I said the first name, and had directed me to the office of someone entirely different, but with the same first name. I'm so relieved to hear that I'm not going completely crazy, and even better this woman then gives me very detailed directions to the office of the ACTUAL person I have the interview with, which turns out to be upstairs. I follow her directions no problem-- only once again I find myself in an empty corridor with random unnamed rooms. After a couple futile wanders through, I finally find someone else to ask for directions, but she has no idea what I'm talking about, and a map on the wall only confuses me further by showing many corridors that don't seem to exist. Eventually, I find myself back in a stairway, and as by this time it's almost 4:30 I admit defeat and just go home. By then I was just glad to escape from that creepy building, cause I was starting to feel like I was trapped in a nightmare! I then had to write an e-mail to the interviewer explaining why I hadn't shown up. Quite honestly, I was expecting to hear no more from him, because someone not showing up for an interview then offering some feeble-sounding excuse about not being able to find the room does not really seem like someone who would be very organised or competent in a job. (although I did conveniently leave out the part where I forget the address in the first place) But yesterday I had the nicest e-mail back from him, saying how he felt terrible that I hadn't been able to find his office, and rescheduling the interview for tomorrow afternoon-- and this time he's even going to come meet me at the main entrance, lol! And he even signed it with a happy face! So now I feel really pressured to be really good at the interview & get the job, because how sad would it be if after all this I'm total rubbish in the interview? Okay, well enough of that epic story. At the moment I'm just glad to have gotten my essay out of the way, was shite as usual though not quite so tortuous to write as some, at least was relatively short. I'm giving myself the day off before I tackle my next assignment, as I need some R&R after being up so late last night. Except, Jude is on Conan tonight, which I really want to see, esp after skipping him on Letterman to watch Ewan. So we shall see if I can manage to stay up that late. I'm wondering what on earth this could be, when I open it up & see this: You must watch Oprah on Friday. 4pm here. Could be different in your part of the world. The cast of the new Bridget Jones will be on!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I am so excited. I will phone at the weekend once I have recovered. Love Mumsy xxxx ROFL, Mum really cracks me up sometimes.
